### Steps to reproduce

In #18308 we found that running `cd\` will do different things depending on the operating system. 

Steps:
1. Navigate to any directory above your drive's root level. >  `Set-Location Drive:/LizardPhotos/Skinks`
2. Run `Set-Location \` or `cd\`
3. You should now be at your drive's root on windows, or your filesystem root on Linux & Mac.

### Expected behavior

```console
Windows, Mac, and Linux set location as the root of the current drive on`cd\`
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Windows sets location to the root of the current drive.
Mac and Linux sets location to the filesystem root.
```

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
By default Unix haven't a drive and it is ok `cd\` to move to a root of current volume. But what if user uses a drive on Unix? Should we follow Windows behavior and move to a root of current drive?
```powershell
cd Temp:\
New-Item test -ItemType Directory
cd test
cd\
```

_I'd prefer consistency on all platforms._ Otherwise, why do we need the drives if the cmdlets ignore them?

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
While consistency across platforms is generally desirable, I fear that's not an option here:

On Unix, if you make `/` refer to the root of a drive (which on Unix is by definition only ever a PS drive), you won't be able to change to the actual file-system root whenever the current location is drive-based.

Pragmatically speaking:

* _Interactively_, typing, say, `Set-Location Temp:/` isn't too much of a hardship.
* _Programmatically_, you can use the following to switch to the root of the _current drive_, on all platforms (which would obviously be too cumbersome interactively):
   * `Set-Location ($PWD.Path -replace '(?<=[\\/]).*')`

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
> _Programmatically_, you can use the following to switch to the root of the _current drive_, on all platforms (which would obviously be too cumbersome interactively):
> * `Set-Location ($PWD.Path -replace '(?<=[\\/]).*')`

Since some of us already redefine CD to be something other than an alias for set location, that could be incorporated into a CD function.

/  is defined as a PS Drive on linux to ensure that cd / does in PowerShell what it does in other unix/linux shells 
What happens in all shells on the same OS is consistent rather than making pwsh on linux "windows like" and annoying linux oriented folks.

title: Set-Location \  behaviour inconsistent between operating systems
